> Standard snake movement: when you move, the head goes to the new position, and each body segment moves to the previous position of the segment ahead. So the tail segment is removed unless you eat food.
> 
> Specifically: if no food eaten, head moves to new cell, each body segment moves to the position of the previous segment, so the tail cell is vacated.
> 
> If food eaten, head moves to food cell, new segment is added at the tail, so tail doesn't move; instead, a new segment is added where the tail was, so the snake grows.

> "Life-span: Disappears after N turns (N = life_span). Countdown decreases every turn (including current)."
> 
> So for a food at turn t with life span L, it will be present for L turns, including turn t. After L turns, it disappears. So at turn t, life span L, it decreases to L-1 at turn t+1, and so on, until life span 0, it disappears before the next turn.
> 
> In this case, turn 28, food at (1,5) has life span 1, so it will disappear after turn 28, meaning it's only available on turn 28. If not eaten on turn 28, it's gone.
> 
> Similarly, (6,2) life span 4, so available until turn 28+3=31? Turn t with life span L: present from turn t to turn t + L - 1.
> 
> At turn t, life span L, countdown starts. After turn t, life span becomes L-1, and so on. When life span reaches 0, it disappears before the next turn.
> 
> So for (1,5) at turn 28, life span 1: it is present on turn 28, and if not eaten, disappears before turn 29.
> 
> For (6,2), life span 4: present from turn 28 to turn 31 (since 28 to 28+3=31, 4 turns: 28,29,30,31).
> 
> Life span L means it will be available for L more turns including current. So at turn t, it has L turns left, so it disappears after turn t + L - 1.
> 
> Standard: if life span is N at turn t, it will disappear after turn t + N - 1. For example, N=1, disappears after turn t, so only on turn t. N=2, available turn t and t+1, disappears before t+2.
